title: Samuel Gillott
text:
Sir Samuel Gillott (29 October 1838 – 29 June 1913) was an Australian lawyer and politician, commonly known as a former <a href="Lord%20Mayor%20of%20Melbourne">Lord Mayor of Melbourne</a>.
Early life.
Gillott was born in the city of <a href="Sheffield">Sheffield</a>, then in the <a href="West%20Riding%20of%20Yorkshire">West Riding of Yorkshire</a>, <a href="England">England</a>, the son of Joseph and Elizabeth Gillott. Educated in <a href="Sheffield%20Grammar%20School">Sheffield Grammar School</a>, Gillott moved to <a href="Melbourne">Melbourne</a>, Australia at the age of 17, in 1856. He was employed by a law firm, Vaughan, Moule & Seddon, and received his law degree from the <a href="University%20of%20Melbourne">University of Melbourne</a>. Immediately after he started practicing law, Vaughan, Moule & Seddon offered him a <a href="partnership">partnership</a>. During the 1890s, Gillott specialized in <a href="Magistrates%27%20court%20%28England%20and%20Wales%29">police court</a> practice, with a firm exception being the <a href="David%20Syme%23Protectionism">Speight v. Syme libel case</a>.
Politics.
Gillott was elected as Mayor of Melbourne in 1896, but lost his mayorship in 1899 by one vote. In November 1899, Gillott was elected to the seat of <a href="Electoral%20district%20of%20East%20Melbourne">East Melbourne</a>, in the <a href="Victorian%20Legislative%20Assembly">Victorian Legislative Assembly</a>; he held this seat until December 1906. He became President of the <a href="Law%20Institute">Law Institute</a> in 1900. In the same year, Gillott was re-elected as the Mayor of Melbourne. Promoted to <a href="Lord%20Mayor">Lord Mayor</a> in 1901, Gillott was <a href="Knight%20Bachelor">knight</a>ed in the same year during the visit to Australia of the Duke and Duchess of Cornwall and York (later <a href="George%20V">King George V</a> and <a href="Mary%20of%20Teck">Queen Mary</a>). In 1901, under the state ministry of Sir <a href="George%20Turner%20%28Australian%20politician%29">George Turner</a>, Gillott was given the role of Honorary Minister. After the Turner Government's fall that year, he stayed on the ministry, becoming <a href="Attorney%20General">Attorney General</a>. In 1904, under the premiership of Sir <a href="Thomas%20Bent">Thomas Bent</a>, Gillott became the <a href="Chief%20Secretary%20of%20New%20South%20Wales">Chief Secretary</a> and the Minister for Labour.
In May 1906, controversy arose for Gillott when a <a href="Demagogy">demagogue reformer</a>, <a href="William%20Judkins">William Judkins</a>, held him responsible for <a href="illegal%20gambling">illegal gambling</a>. As proof, Judkins named <a href="John%20Wren">John Wren</a>'s illegal betting schemes, which he held as evidence of a corrupt government. As a result of the controversial issue, Thomas Bent agreed to prohibit off-course betting. Later that year, Gillott introduced the gaming suppression bill. Following the gambling controversy, <a href="John%20Norton%20%28journalist%29">John Norton</a>'s newspaper, "<a href="The%20Truth%20%28Sydney%20newspaper%29">The Truth</a>", published an article on Gillott, linking him to a well known <a href="brothel">brothel</a> proprietor, <a href="Caroline%20Hodgson">Caroline Hodgson</a>, and revealing his financial dealings with her since 1877. Resigning from parliament and the ministry after these allegations, Gillott returned to England, where he stayed for almost a year.
Returning to Australia after a year in England, he resumed his seat in the Melbourne City Council, and became president and councillor of the <a href="RMIT%20University">Working Men's College of Melbourne</a>. On another visit to England in 1913, Gillott died after falling down a flight of stairs at night in Sheffield. He was 74 years of age. His body was returned to Australia and was interred at <a href="Melbourne%20General%20Cemetery">Melbourne General Cemetery</a>.
